CMPT 295 - Unit – Microprocessor Design & Instruction Execution

Lecture 27

  • Combinational and Sequential Logic Circuits

Last Lecture

  • We have now started to explore how the microprocessor executes machine instructions (series of 0’s and 1’s)
    • More specifically, how its datapath can be constructed
  • Microprocessor itself is …
    • Made of resistors, capacitors, diodes, and transistors
    • Billions of them, so understanding how these small components work together is too detailed hence too onerous
    • So we resort to abstraction (black box) in order to understand their functioning
      • We use logic gates to abstract the “how these small components work together” by highlighting “what they do”, i.e., perform a Boolean function
    • What is important for us to understand is that hardware components (such as logic gates) have propagation delay
      • Signals (0’s and 1’s) take time to propagate through them

Today’s Menu

  • Instruction Set Architecture (ISA)
    • Definition of ISA
  • Instruction Set design
    • Design principles
    • Look at an example of an instruction set: MIPS
    • Create our own
    • ISA evaluation
  • (highlighted) Implementation of a microprocessor (CPU) based on an ISA
    • (highlighted) Execution of machine instructions (datapath)
    • Intro to logic design + (highlighted) Combinational logic + Sequential logic circuit
    • Sequential execution of machine instructions
    • Pipelined execution of machine instructions + Hazards

From our last lecture - Digital circuits

  • In order to understand how the microprocessor executes these machine instructions (series of 0’s and 1’s), we need to have a look at the components of a microprocessor and how they function:
    1. Combinational logic -> manipulate bits (compute functions on bits e.g., ADD) (Annotation: Types of components found in a digital system such as a microprocessor)
    2. Memory elements -> store bits
    3. Clock signals -> regulate the update of memory elements
  • and what affects the execution speed of these components such as propagation delay
  • So, we need to understand a few things about digital circuits

Combinational logic circuits - 1

Annotation:

  • output depends only on input
  • given same input produces same output
  • no internet storage

Slide:

  • Made by connecting several logic gates together
  • Compute more complex functions than just AND or XOR
  • Example: Combinational logic circuit that adds 2 bits together
    • Half Adder diagram, inputs are A,B; outputs are S (sum) and C (carry)
      • S=A⊕B,S=A∧BS = A\oplus B, S = A\land BS=A⊕B,S=A∧B
    • Black Diagram (black box) of Half Adder:
      • Inputs = A,B; Outputs = S,C
  • Propagation delay: “1 gate” delay
  • http://sullystationtechnologies.com/ichalfadder.html

Example of an integrated circuit (IC)

SN74LVC2G157

2G157 Back to where this is mentioned later on

8 pins in the following layout, the number is follow by its label:

8 VCCV_{CC}VCC​ 7 G‾\overline{G}G 6 A‾/B\overline{A}/BA/B 5 YYY
1 AAA 2 BBB 3 Y‾\overline{Y}Y 4 GND\text{GND}GND
  • 4 and 8 are not connected to the rest of the pins.
  • 3 may be connected, but I can’t tell how
  • pin 5 = Y=(A∧(A/BG‾‾))∧(B∧(G‾⊕A‾/B))Y = (A \land (\overline{A/B \overline{G}})) \land (B \land (\overline{G} \oplus \overline{A}/B))Y=(A∧(A/BG​))∧(B∧(G⊕A/B))
  • all other pins are inputs, pin 5 is the only output

Combinational logic cuircuits - 2

  • Can connect several combinational logic curcuits together to perform more complex functions and/or perform funtion on a wider input.
  • What does this curcuit do?

Circuit diagram:

Inputs: A,B,C

Outputs: S,C

S=C⊕(A⊕B)C=(A∧B)∨(C∧(A⊕B)) S = C\oplus (A\oplus B)\\ C = (A\land B) \lor (C \land (A\oplus B)) S=C⊕(A⊕B)C=(A∧B)∨(C∧(A⊕B))

End of curcuit diagram

Every row are associated equations:

Carry in 0: 02A+02B=02C02S 0^{A}_{2} + 0^{B}_{2} = 0^{C}_{2} 0^S_{2} 02A​+02B​=02C​02S​ Carry in = 0: 02A+12B=02C−12S− 0^{A}_{2} + 1^{B}_{2} = 0^{C-}_{2} 1^{S-}_{2} 02A​+12B​=02C−​12S−​
Carry in 0: 12A+02B=02C12S 1^{A}_{2} + 0^{B}_{2} = 0^{C}_{2} {1}^{S}_{2} 12A​+02B​=02C​12S​ Carry in = 0: 02A+12B=02C−12S− 0^{A}_{2} + 1^{B}_{2} = 0^{C-}_{2} {1}^{S-}_{2} 02A​+12B​=02C−​12S−​
Carry in = 1: 02A+02B=02C12S 0^{A}_{2} + 0^{B}_{2} = 0^{C}_{2} {1}^{S}_{2} 02A​+02B​=02C​12S​ Carry in = 1: 02A+12B=12C02S 0^{A}_{2} + 1^{B}_{2} = 1^{C}_{2} {0}^{S}_{2} 02A​+12B​=12C​02S​
Carry in = 1: 02A+12B=12C02S 0^{A}_{2} + 1^{B}_{2} = 1^{C}_{2} 0^{S}_{2} 02A​+12B​=12C​02S​ Carry out = 1: 12A+12B=12C12S 1^{A}_{2} + 1^{B}_{2} = 1^{C}_{2} 1^{S}_{2} 12A​+12B​=12C​12S​
  • Propagation delay: “3 gate” delay

Combinational logic circuits - 3

Annotation: Hw: Lavel all input & output times!

Annotation, equation; indexed from highest to lowest (i.e. C3=1C_{3} = 1C3​=1, C0=0C_{0} = 0C0​=0):

C=11002A=01102B=10112S=A+B+C=100012C4=1 C = \text{1100}_{2}\\ A = \text{0110}_{2}\\ B = \text{1011}_{2}\\ S = A + B + C = \text{10001}_{2}\\ C_{4} = 1 C=11002​A=01102​B=10112​S=A+B+C=100012​C4​=1

C4=1C_{4} = 1C4​=1 when the result width of A+B+CA+B+CA+B+C os larger than w (in this case: 4). Now back to the rest of the slide.

  • Can connect several combinational logic circuits together as black boxes (black box design can be modular)
  • The resulting circuit can operate on word size data such as integral values and memory addresses
  • Example: Full Adder operating on data of word size 4 (w = 4) aka 4-bit ripple carry adder

Start of logic diagram:

FA = Full Adder

Inputs:

  • A0−3=01102A_{0-3} = \text{0110}_{2}A0−3​=01102​
  • B0−3=11012B_{0-3} = \text{1101}_{2}B0−3​=11012​
  • C0=0C_{0} = 0C0​=0

Internals:

  • For n from 1 to 3:
    • Cn=FA(Cn−1,Bn−1,An−1)C_{n} = \text{FA}(C_{n-1}, B_{n-1}, A_{n-1})Cn​=FA(Cn−1​,Bn−1​,An−1​)
  • C1−3=0112C_{1-3} = \text{011}_{2}C1−3​=0112​

Outputs:

  • Sn=FA(An,Bn,Cn)=00012S_{n} = \text{FA}(A_{n}, B_{n}, C_{n}) = \text{0001}_{2}Sn​=FA(An​,Bn​,Cn​)=00012​
  • C4=FA(A3,B3,C3)=12C_{4} = \text{FA}(A_{3}, B_{3}, C_{3}) = 1_{2}C4​=FA(A3​,B3​,C3​)=12​

End of logic diagram:

Block Diagram of full-adder:

Label: FA-4

Inputs:

  • A4A_{4}A4​
  • B4B_{4}B4​
  • CinC_{\text{in}}Cin​

Outputs:

  • S4S_{4}S4​
  • CoutC_{\text{out}}Cout​

where … B4=[B3,B2,B1,B0]B_{4} = [B_{3}, B_{2}, B_{1}, B_{0}]B4​=[B3​,B2​,B1​,B0​]

End of block diagram

Homework

Why is the propagation delay of this Full Adder 4 (also known as a 4-bit (w-bit) ripple carry adder) 9 gates (2w + 1 gates) where w is the number of bits (as opposed to 12 gates -> 4 x 3 gate p.d.)?

Large diagram containing 4 of the same of these diagrams.

ALU - Example of combinational logic circuit

  • Arithmetic/logic unit found in microprocessor
    • Black box diagram
  • ALU executes data manipulation machine instructions (defined in the ISA)

Diagram of ALU

p = 32 or 64

Inputs:

  • ApA_{p}Ap​
  • BpB_{p}Bp​
  • S4S_{4}S4​
  • Condition codes

Outputs:

  • resultp\text{result}_{p}resultp​

End diagram of ALU

S operation
0001 A+B
0010 A-B
1000 A*B
0100 A^B
0101 A&B

Summary: Combinational logic circuits

  • Definition: A combinational logic circuit computes a function, where its outputs is based only on its inputs
  • Contains logic gates
    • Input values propagate through logic gates of combinational logic circuit whenever they change
    • Input to a logic gate must come from either input of combinational logic circuit itself (input to black box) or output of other logic gates
    • Outputs of two or more logic gates cannot be connected together unless it is via a logic gate
  • Acyclic: there are no feedback loops
  • Does not require a clock signal, does not contain memory elements -> does not store (remember) anything

From our last lecture - Digital circuits

  • In order to understand how the microprocessor executes these machine instructions (series of 0’s and 1’s), we need to have a look at the components of a microprocessor and how they function:
    1. Combinational logic -> manipulate bits (compute functions on bits e.g., ADD)
    2. (highlighted) Memory elements -> store bits
    3. (highlighted) Clock signals -> regulate the update of memory elements (Annotation: The two highlighted items combined is labeled “Sequential logic circuit”)
  • and what affects the execution speed of these components such as propagation delay
  • So, we need to understand a few things about digital circuits

Sequential logic circuit

// TODO

  • Has a state -> memory (it has internal storage)
  • “Clocked”

  • Has at least 2 input: *Data to be remembered and *Clock

  • Has at least one output: *Value remembered (during an earlier clock cycle)

  • Example of a sequential logic circuit is a memory element

  • Simplest memory element: D-type flip-flop 15

  • Example of memory element components with which we are already familiar: registers

Memory elements and Clock signals

  • Memory element #1 -> clocked registers a.k.a. hardware registers
  • On the microprocessor

  • A clocked register stores 1 bit (state)

  • Synchronized by system-wide clock

clocked register

  • System-wide clock
  • A system-wide clock sends 0 1 0 1 0 1 0 1…
  • Clock period: 1 full cycle duration:

  • Clock frequency: 1/period

  • How clocked registers work:

  • Output current state

  • Input next state 16

  • Next state remembered only on rising edge of clock

CLOCK

Carnegie Mellon

Summary

19

 Combinational logic circuits *Made of many logic gates *Multi-functional combinational logic circuits such as ALU have control input lines to indicate which function to perform *Combinational logic circuits do not store (remember) values  Sequential logic circuits *Made of combinational logic circuits, memory elements (clocked registers) and clock *Circuit that “remembers” values (state) and perform computations on these values
